Most things that are really harmful don't taste very good. For example, the cyanogen compounds. Some occur naturally in things like almonds, apple seeds, peach pits, etc. In fact, bitter almonds are bitter because of the cyanogen. If you eat too many it is possible to kill yourself.
 
 You are thinking of things that are harmful in excess - too much animal fat, too much starch, too much sugar, and just plain too much. In fact, fat, starch, and sugar are necessary for us to live. The living great apes live on a diet high in fiber, with lots of fruit, and a much lower percentage of animal protein and fat. But they still eat fat, starch and sugar.

What you describe is only possible because we have learned to manipulate our food supply. Instead of eating fruit for something sweet, humans refine sugar and then put it in almost everything. We eat piles of potatoes, breads, and pasta, each of which is reduced to more sugar by our bodies. Cro-Magnons didn't bake cookies made with refined and bleached flour and refined granulated sugar. They ate fruit because it tasted good and benefited from the nutrients that have been removed from flour and sugar.
 
 By the way, it's not instinct.

actually, our sense of taste is very dynamic. if you eat a iced cup cake and then drink some juice, the juice doesnt taste sweet at all, possibly inhibiting your desire for more sweet food. similarly, the mere fact that your stomach reacts badly to too much sweets, but is relieved when you eat something different to neutralize the taste. these are natural mechanisms that prevent us from only eating foods that "taste good"
 
 i love peanut butter, but we all know that peanut butter by itself is near inpalatable. but on bread it tastes great, to a certain extent, then you want something sweet (jelly, milk, juice). because what appeals to our taste adapts so readily to the circumstance, it pretty much reduces our tendency to eat too much of any single food.
